Describing what you would buy if you won the lottery
Fashion
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
The standard was incredibly high at last night's [k]fashion show[/k]. It was really amazing to see.
Yes, I agree. Eddie Richardson's [k]collection[/k] was particularly impressive.
I have to say, I thought Maria Corona's effort this [k]season[/k] left a lot to be desired. I was expecting a lot more from her.
I don't agree to be honest. I thought her choice of [k]catwalk[/k] models was a refreshing change. And some of the collection had some real style.
It was nice to see some different types of model, that's true. But I thought most of her designs were horrendous!
Wow, that's very strong criticism. Which pieces are you talking about?
Like that purple and blue [k]striped[/k] dress at the end of the show!
Yes, but I guess that being a [k]fashion designer[/k] is about taking risks. Sometimes people love it and sometimes not.
Paul
Julia

If I were a million­aire
I don't know how much more of this job I can take. The hours go by so slowly.
You could always play the [k]lottery[/k]. If you win you could quit your job!
I would play it if I thought there was any chance of winning!
Well, if I won a million pounds, I'd live a life of [k]luxury[/k]!
I'd [k]invest[/k] most of it in the housing market and then put the rest in the bank.
That's pretty boring Andrew! I'd sail around the world in a massive [k]yacht[/k]. Wouldn't you do anything exciting?
Maybe I would buy myself a [k]designer suit[/k].
How adventurous of you! And you could quit your job of course!
Andrew
Claire
What would you do or what things would you buy if you won the lottery?
If I won the lottery I'd love to buy a house on the beach, with a view of the sea. I would buy a convertible car for my dad because he has always wanted one.
Grammar: Mixed conditionals
The sentence talks about a hypothetical situation.
If I had worked harder at university, I would have got a better result.
True or false?
If the weather is nice, we'll go to the beach.
If I had more money, I'd go on holiday with you.
Conditional sentences can be real or hypothetical, and refer to different times:
1st Conditional: If It rains, I'll take a taxi. - (real and future)
The sentence mixes different conditionals.
If I had worked harder, I would have a better job now.
If I had bought a ticket, I would be going with them to the concert later.
If I had known you were going, I would have got a ticket.
Mixed Conditionals mix the clauses of different conditional sentences. These are usually hypothetical, but can also refer to real situations.

If I had worked harder (hypothetical past), I would have a better job now (hypothetical present).
If I had bought a ticket (hypothetical past), I would be going with them to the concert later (hypothetical future).
The mixed conditional sentence refers to a possible future situation.
If I hadn't lost my wallet, I'd buy you a drink.
If he left the house at 9 o'clock, he won't arrive before the show starts.
If I were more intelligent, I would have passed my exam.

Mixed conditional sentences often mix 2nd and 3rd conditional clauses to talk about hypothetical situations. But it is also possible to mix 1st conditional clauses to talk about more likely future events.
If he left the house at 9 o'clock, he won't arrive before the show starts.
[k]If we[/k] [k]had come here[/k] [k]in June,[/k] [k]the weather[/k] [k]would[/k] [k]be better.[/k]
[k]If you[/k] [k]loved[/k] [k]me,[/k] [k]you[/k] [k]wouldn't[/k] [k]have[/k] [k]said that.[/k]
[k]We[/k] [k]wouldn't[/k] [k]be[/k] [k]in this situation[/k] [k]if I[/k] [k]hadn't[/k] [k]lost the bag.[/k]

We can put the 'conditional clause' or the 'main clause' at the start of a conditional sentence and it doesn't affect the meaning.
In the conditional clause, the Past Perfect tense is used for hypothetical past conditions, Past Simple is used for general hypothetical conditions.
In the main clause, 'would have + past participle' is used for past situations and 'would + infinitive' is used for general situations.

If you loved me, you wouldn't have said that.
If we had come here in June, the weather would have been better.
If we hadn't [k]missed[/k] the bus, [k]we'd be[/k] in the concert right now.
miss
we'd been

Mixed Conditional - not have
We [k]wouldn't have had|would not have had[/k] the accident if you were a more careful driver.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
Mixed Conditional - ever buy
I would buy you a drink if you [k]had ever bought[/k] me drinks!
Mixed Conditional - treat
If you [k]had treated[/k] him better when you were together, he would still be your boyfriend.
